professors.name: Sophia
professors.university: Athens University of Economics and Business

theses.title: User Behavior and Network Cybersecurity: An Empirical Study
theses.summary: This thesis investigates how typical user actions affect network security posture. Using traffic logs and simulated workflows, we quantify the impact of routine behaviors on intrusion detection signals, false positives, and policy compliance. Findings show that modeling normal usage patterns reduces noise in alerts and improves incident triage without degrading detection accuracy.

theses.title: Software Reliability through Normal Behavior Modeling
theses.summary: This thesis explores how modeling standard software execution patterns improves reliability and resilience. Using controlled experiments with common applications, we identify deviations that signal defects or vulnerabilities. The results show that embedding behavior-aware checks into software pipelines reduces unexpected crashes and enhances fault tolerance, offering a structured approach to dependable system design.

theses.title: Enhancing Human–Computer Interaction through User Behavior Analysis
theses.summary: This thesis investigates how analyzing recurring interaction patterns can improve user interface design. By collecting empirical data from usability tests, we identify consistent behaviors and map them to design challenges. Results demonstrate that incorporating behavioral insights leads to more intuitive interfaces, reduces user error rates, and increases overall satisfaction in digital environments.

theses.title: Data Preprocessing in Machine Learning: Why Normalization Matters
theses.summary: This thesis examines the role of data preprocessing and normalization in modern machine learning algorithms. Through experiments on classification and regression tasks, we compare raw versus normalized datasets and measure impacts on accuracy, convergence speed, and stability. The study highlights that systematic preprocessing is critical for reducing bias, improving generalization, and enabling reproducible results in applied ML.

theses.title: Monitoring System Performance for Predictive Maintenance
theses.summary: This thesis investigates how continuous monitoring of system performance indicators can support predictive maintenance in computer infrastructures. We design and test models that correlate CPU usage, memory consumption, and network activity with early signs of failures. Results indicate that proactive monitoring reduces downtime, improves service availability, and offers cost-efficient maintenance strategies.

theses.title: Optimizing Neural Networks for Edge Computing Devices
theses.summary: This thesis explores lightweight deep learning architectures tailored for Internet of Things and edge computing scenarios. We evaluate pruning, quantization, and model compression techniques across benchmark datasets, measuring accuracy, latency, and energy consumption. Findings show that compact models such as MobileNet and quantized CNNs deliver efficient inference while preserving acceptable accuracy, enabling AI deployment on resource-constrained devices.

theses.title: Advancing Natural Language Processing with Zero-Shot Learning
theses.summary: This thesis investigates zero-shot learning techniques in natural language processing. Using models such as GPT and BERT, we evaluate performance across sentiment analysis, text classification, and translation tasks without labeled training data. Results highlight strengths in adaptability but also limitations in low-resource languages. The study proposes a hybrid framework combining zero-shot methods with domain adaptation to improve accuracy in real-world NLP applications.

theses.title: Blockchain for Secure and Transparent Voting Systems
theses.summary: This thesis evaluates blockchain frameworks for implementing electronic voting systems. We design a prototype that demonstrates voter anonymity, ballot integrity, and tamper resistance using decentralized ledgers and cryptographic proofs. The analysis also considers scalability, usability, and accessibility challenges. Results suggest that blockchain-based voting can enhance trust in elections, though practical deployment requires addressing performance and governance issues.

theses.title: Quantum Computing and the Future of Cryptography
theses.summary: This thesis explores how quantum algorithms such as Shors and Grovers challenge classical cryptographic protocols. We analyze the risks posed to RSA, ECC, and symmetric schemes, and evaluate candidate post-quantum algorithms for secure communication. The study emphasizes the urgent need for migration to quantum-resistant standards and provides recommendations for phased adoption in critical infrastructures.

theses.title: A Comparative Study of Machine Learning Algorithms
theses.summary: This thesis provides an overview of widely used machine learning algorithms and their applications. We compare decision trees, support vector machines, neural networks, and ensemble methods across multiple datasets. Evaluation criteria include accuracy, training efficiency, and scalability. The study highlights trade-offs between interpretability and performance, offering guidance for selecting appropriate algorithms in practical projects.

theses.title: Big Data Analytics for Social Media Trends
theses.summary: This thesis analyzes social media platforms using big data technologies to identify emerging trends and user behaviors. We employ Hadoop and Spark frameworks to process large-scale datasets and apply sentiment analysis and clustering methods. The findings reveal how online discourse evolves over time and provide insights into predicting viral content and audience engagement.

theses.title: Mobile Applications for E-Commerce Platforms
theses.summary: This thesis focuses on the design and implementation of mobile applications that enhance user experience in e-commerce. Using cross-platform development frameworks, we prototype an app with secure authentication, product catalog browsing, and integrated payment systems. Evaluation shows improved usability and engagement, highlighting how mobile apps can increase sales and customer satisfaction in online retail.

theses.title: Data Security Challenges in Cloud Computing
theses.summary: This thesis examines major security challenges in cloud environments, including data breaches, insider threats, and insecure APIs. We review current cryptographic solutions and propose an enhanced access control framework tested on a simulated cloud platform. Results show improved confidentiality and integrity of sensitive information while maintaining system performance.

theses.title: Optimization Techniques in Graph Theory
theses.summary: This thesis investigates optimization problems in graph theory and their real-world applications. We focus on shortest path algorithms, network flow, and graph coloring, applying them to case studies in logistics and communication networks. Experimental results highlight performance trade-offs and demonstrate how advanced heuristics can significantly reduce computational complexity.

theses.title: Blockchain and Decentralized Finance Applications
theses.summary: This thesis explores the role of blockchain in enabling decentralized finance (DeFi). We examine smart contracts, liquidity pools, and decentralized exchanges, analyzing their potential to replace traditional financial intermediaries. Case studies highlight opportunities and risks, including scalability, regulatory challenges, and security vulnerabilities. The findings provide a balanced view of DeFi’s transformative potential.

theses.title: Augmented Reality in Education: Tools for Interactive Learning
theses.summary: This thesis investigates the use of augmented reality (AR) applications in education. We design prototypes for classroom environments that enable interactive visualization of complex subjects such as biology and physics. Evaluation with students and teachers shows that AR tools enhance engagement, improve comprehension, and foster collaborative learning experiences.

theses.title: Artificial Intelligence Applications in Healthcare
theses.summary: This thesis explores the use of artificial intelligence to support diagnostics and treatment in healthcare. We evaluate machine learning models for medical image classification, disease prediction, and patient monitoring. Results demonstrate improved diagnostic accuracy and early detection capabilities, while also discussing ethical considerations and data privacy concerns in clinical adoption.

theses.title: Robotics in Industrial Automation
theses.summary: This thesis examines the integration of robotics into industrial automation systems. We analyze robotic arms, autonomous guided vehicles, and sensor networks for manufacturing optimization. Case studies demonstrate improvements in efficiency, precision, and workplace safety. The research also discusses challenges such as high deployment costs and workforce adaptation.

theses.title: Game Development with Unreal Engine: Design and Implementation
theses.summary: This thesis explores modern game development practices using Unreal Engine. We design and implement a 3D game prototype to demonstrate core concepts such as physics simulation, AI-driven characters, and immersive environments. Performance benchmarks highlight both strengths and limitations of Unreal Engine, offering insights into best practices for interactive entertainment projects.

theses.title: Artificial Intelligence for Patient Monitoring
theses.summary: This thesis evaluates the use of AI systems for continuous patient monitoring and clinical decision support. We implement models for anomaly detection in vital signs and predictive analytics for patient deterioration. Case studies in simulated hospital settings show that AI can enhance response times, improve patient safety, and support medical staff, while raising considerations around data privacy and reliability.

theses.title: Cybersecurity Threat Detection with Machine Learning
theses.summary: This thesis develops and evaluates machine learning models for real-time detection of cybersecurity threats. Using datasets of network traffic and intrusion attempts, we train classifiers to distinguish malicious activity from normal behavior. The evaluation shows that ensemble methods improve detection accuracy while reducing false positives, offering practical value for modern security operations centers.
